COMMUNICATION
QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY SPEECH
To the Editor of The Times.

Sir,-In a former letter I simply noted
from the press that there was dissatisfaction
which seemed to exist in connection with the
late 24th of May sports, and as the
name of Mr. Alexander Taylor was mentioned
in the honesty of every member of that
committee. Judge then of my surprise
to receive a communication from Mr. Taylor
which will have no doubt in the mind of
any one that for some unknown reason
the committee did not want to publish
the statement made by him. Had he
not been silent would they not have waited
for the name of anyone before doing
the thing? If the committee had been
collectors and expenditures have been
balanced why not publish the fact as a curi-
osity? But the silence of the committee
of Mr. Alexander's name being known
will not excuse the committee from
responsibility. If the shoe does pinch, let a meeting be
called and let each collector be charged
with having been the sole cause of the
sports and for the benefit of the public.
To the front.

Block.

A. L. ASHDOWN,

RETTS & Gwynne

No longer known to the public of Prince Albert and surrounding country, take great pleasure in announcing that every department of their business is again complete with a fine assortment of the Latest and Best Selected Class of Goods. An endless variety of every kind of

DRY GOODS

Now on exhibition, conspicuous among them being some choice selections in

Bunting and De Beige, Dress Goods, Elegant Infant Robes, Evening Shaws and Kid Gloves. Frillings, Lace Trimmings, Corsets, Hosiery, Smallwares and a full line of Crout's Celebrated Black Silk Capes. Our Brown and White Ducks, Ticking, Sheetings, Jeans and Cambrics, together with our English and American Prints

Make this branch of our business the most complete ever opened here, and at prices without an equal in the country. Grand Display of

READY-MADE CLOTHING BOUGHT AND PAID FOR.

Men's, Youth's and Boys' Suits, representing one of the largest, and most fashionable clothing units ever shown in this district, and owing to our disappointment in not securing larger premises, we have decided to offer for the next THREE DAYS every article in this department at coal prices which cannot help our existing opposition.

Men's Knit Jerseys, Shirts, Ties, Collars and Gloves, Hard and Soft and American Hats and Helmets and a Big Outfit of Straw Goods—Every article new and stylish

TWENTY-FOUR DOZEN PAIRS OF

Our now Celebrated Double-stitched Overalls

READY FOR INSPECTION.

We take pleasure in assuring that we are still in a position to maintain the reputation we have gained in our

GROCERY DEPARTMENT.

As usual, our stock of Canned Goods is unequalled, while our Groceries, Spices, etc., will be found pure and unadulterated. Every article has been selected for its usefulness, not cheapness.

STAPLE CROCKERY—The best in the market. In PATENT MEDICINES we show a full line of every kind of staple goods.

We employ no agents to buy our goods. The entire stock has been selected with a knowledge of the requirements of this country, and every article will be found as represented.

LOCAL AND GENERAL NEWS.

What about Johnny and his wife?

River bathing is being indulged in by the boys.

Ladies Visiting Cards, best quality, at the Town.

A special train for the H.R.C. passed down this morning.

J.M. Campbell is erecting a store front of Campbell's block.

Messrs. H. F. Fletcher, J.C. Macdonald and Locks left for the Appalacian Mountains.

The citizens of Moose Jaw expect to have cool this coming winter for 25 degrees.

The Ferry Johnson boat race took place at East Portage on the 14th of June.

Ferry was very good.

Every rig was in great demand last Sunday, the weather being beautiful and the river smooth.

The engine and boiler for Mr. Thomas McKay's new mill is expected to arrive by the first week in July.

The last few days have been excessively warm, and the black fly is consequently becoming quite numerous.

Don't forget the skating match on Dominion Day. We hope to see every keen and enthusiastic skater there.

We are by the East Portage Post Office, Mr. D. Nisbet, who lives in this place, has written us from his home.

Nearly every mail which arrives in this town comes against a good or bad wind, and the post office is always wet.

J.O. Davis & Co. foremen arrived on Saturday, and went off with good things to eat and drink, and plenty of the most substantial.

We would like to see the stock holders in the Royal Curling and Skating Club that the first half payment is due on the 1st of July.

Mr. J.O. Davis is so occupied at this work another large supply of hardware, among other things a splendid assortment of curling sticks.

Sawing has commenced in Moose & Macdonald's saw mill, and there are now a fifth lumber yard in the town.

Applications to building operations.

The Tripos affair has met with a great loss, dear old Zola has been killed by a horse. Any case arising out of this affair will be prosecuted.

It is expected that Bishop Cranston will arrive here from Winnipeg this week.

Rev. A. Whitehouse has been transferred to the Montreal Methodist Conference.

The Stationery Committee has assigned him a new field of labor at Goose Basin and will be glad to see him there.

A horse belonging to Mr. Wm. Dalworth ran away Sunday evening and was found in the woods near the school house.

The horse afterwards made his own way to the stable with only the broken shoe.

Mr. Shannan, of the firm of Shannan & McLeod, arrived back home from Winnipeg last Monday. He has purchased a fine horse, which he will ride when he goes on the road and will arrive here in a few days.

There is a curious hall at large in the west end of the town and the owner had better secure a lock or else it will be broken into and the contents stolen.

Several ladies and gentlemen have been disturbed by the noise of the hall, and they have complained and had hardly got inside the door closed when the hall butted the door with great force. We will tip the gentlemen a rifle.

CITY AUCTION MART.

Having closed a General Auctioneering and Commission business in the city of Prince Albert, Messrs. J. H. Ross & Co., bankers, are prepared to run a second-hand auction mart for the benefit of all private residences and others desirous of disposing of any surplus, either for public auction or private sale.
